title: 111_hr5913
content:
The "Text a Tip Act of 2010" establishes a pilot program for texting crime tips. The Attorney General can provide grants to law enforcement agencies for implementing an anonymous tip program via cell phone text messaging. The funds must be used for developing, expanding, or promoting the program, including expenses like salaries, training, technology, and public service promotion. The Attorney General can provide grants to law enforcement agencies for implementing an anonymous tip program via cell phone text messaging. The grant covers expenses related to program operation, promotion, and the Federal share should not exceed 75 percent of the program cost. Grant amounts should supplement non-Federal funds, not replace them. The Federal share of a grant under this Act cannot exceed 75% of the program cost. Grant amounts must supplement non-Federal funds, not replace them. Program requirements under this Act cannot exceed 75% of the program cost and must supplement non-Federal funds. A texting tip program of a State or local law enforcement agency eligible for a grant under this Act must comply with requirements such as administering the program, stripping incoming text messages of identifying information, ensuring the text tip is untraceable, not replacing existing hotlines, and providing sufficient training for law enforcement agency staff. The texting program for law enforcement agencies must ensure text tips are untraceable, not replace existing hotlines, train personnel to respond to tips, and be compatible with most mobile phone providers. It should also include an unidentifiable code for tipsters. The law enforcement agency's texting program should be compatible with most mobile phone providers and include an unidentifiable code for tipsters to send follow-up information. It should also have a feature to abort a tip and not impose any additional fees on the tipster's mobile phone. The law enforcement agency's texting program should promote citizen participation, especially among youth, without imposing additional fees on tipsters' mobile phones. The program should also include a feature to abort a tip in progress. To apply for a grant under this Act, a State or local law enforcement agency must submit an application to the Attorney General with required information. The application must include certifications that the program meets the Act's requirements. Additionally, the agency must provide reports and evaluations as outlined in the Act. SEC. 5. REPORTS AND EVALUATIONS.

Recipients of grants under this Act must submit yearly reports to the Attorney General on the effectiveness of activities funded by the grant. The Attorney General, in turn, must submit a yearly report to the Senate and House Judiciary Committees on the effectiveness of activities under this Act.

SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. The term "texting tip program" allows citizens to text tips anonymously to aid law enforcement in preventing and solving crimes. "Texting" refers to sending written messages from a mobile phone. Authorization of appropriations for the Attorney General to carry out the Act is set at $5,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2011 through 2016.
